Chemistry and Environment, Beihang University, Beijing 100191, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) are potential substitutes for platinum group metal catalysts in hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) for sustainable energy. In this work, a novel machine learning (ML)-based technique for HER performance prediction of TMPs is presented. ΔGH, which assesses catalytic activity, was utilized as the expected target value and data from sources like collected papers and self-calculated data were also employed. The random forest (RFR) technique produced an R2 of 0.89 on the test set, while non-tree ML algorithms were utilized for learning and feedback. Additionally, TMPs of ΔGH were predicted using an original Ensemble learning technique. The ensemble learning method significantly increased the model's predictive effect and strengthened the model's stability and resilience, resulting in an R2 >0.85 on the test set for the tree algorithm model. The SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) algorithm and RFR showed that the geometric means of atomic volume, first ionization energy, and p-orbital electron number significantly impact free energy performance evaluation by tree ML algorithms. These findings can effectively guide the design and development of new products. In conclusion, this approach offers a useful tool to assess TMPs’ performance in HER studies. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Transition metal phosphides Machine learning Hydrogen evolution reaction Ensemble learning Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to the use of fossil fuels, global warming and air pollution have brought great harm to the environment and our daily lives [1–3]. Hydrogen energy, as a clean and renewable energy source, can effectively solve these environmental problems and has aroused widespread research interest. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is an economical way to achieve industrialized and low-cost hydrogen production [4]. Chemical water decomposition HER has become an efficient and sustainable technology due to its advantages such as easy-to-obtain reactants, stable high-purity products, and feasible large-scale production processes, and has received close attention. Water electrolysis hydrogen evolution can be carried out in acidic, neutral, and alkaline media, where the hydrogen evolution performance in acidic media mainly depends on the hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔGH)of the electrocatalys[5,6]. Abghoui et al.[7] reported that TaN, HfN, MoN, and ScN catalyzed HER with overpotentials between -0.09 and -0.34 V. Kim, Peter, Sarkar et al.[8,9] demonstrated that the activity of transition metal carbide (TMC) catalysts is between the low activity of early transition metals and the high activity of Pt/Pt group metal compounds. It is of great research value to be able to indicate the hydrogen evolution ability of electrocatalysts by evaluating the ΔGH of HER [10,11]. Although the hydrogen evolution mechanism in acidic media has been extensively studied and metal volcano diagrams have been realized to optimize electrocatalysts, industrial applications based on this technology still heavily depend on the performance of HER electrocatalysts. Currently, the best hydrogen evolution electrocatalyst material is based on platinum-based precious metals, but its scarcity and high cost severely hinder its large-scale application [12–14]. In order to find more competitive alternatives, researchers have begun to focus on HER electrocatalysts based on transition metals (TM), such as TM compounds and TM single-atom catalysts. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs), as a new type of non-precious metal catalyst, have shown excellent catalytic performance and high stability in fields such as oxygen evolution reaction (OER)[15], hydrogen evolution reaction (HER)[16], oxygen reduction reaction (ORR)[17], and electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction(CO2RR)[18]. TMPs are regarded as low-cost, high-efficiency, and long-life substitutes for platinum group catalysts [19–21]. When evaluating the catalytic activity of TMPs, ΔGH is a key indicator that affects the properties, stability, and activity of catalysts in reactions [22]. Due to the complexity of surface chemical properties, the development of new electrocatalysts still relies on empirical science and trial-and-error experiments. With the development of the Materials Genome Initiative, cooperation between machine learning and materials science continues to expand and deepen, providing a new paradigm for materials discovery and design. In order to reduce costs and shorten computational experimental cycles, data-driven strategies based on machine learning (ML) are expected to accelerate the discovery of potential electrocatalysts. ML has been widely used in material screening, especially in the field of catalyst design [23–25]. For example, Chen et al. [26,27]. used extreme gradient boosting regression (XGBR) to identify potential single-atom catalysts for CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). In addition, Tran and Ulissi et al. [23] developed an active learning framework for accelerating alloy catalyst design, selecting 131 and 258 candidate surfaces for CO2RR and HER respectively. In particular, Cu-Al alloy has been identified as having outstanding CO2RR catalytic activity and has been experimentally verified. These studies demonstrate the importance and applicability of machine learning in catalyst design [28–30]. Computational methods based on machine learning have been applied to predict catalyst activity and selectivity by establishing predictive models through analysis of large amounts of computational data to predict the performance of new catalyst [25]. In this work, we used machine learning methods to predict the ΔGH of TMPs by considering 14 feature descriptors such as Pauling electronegativity, atomic number, covalent radius, van der Waals radius, outermost d orbital electron number, electron affinity energy, first ionization energy, second ionization energy, electron affinity energy, p orbital electron number, etc.; including elemental electronic features, geometric features, as well as their combination analysis in some way analyzed the relationship between various physical features and ΔGH. And through non-tree machine learning algorithm model, tree machine learning algorithm model, ensemble machine learning algorithm model comparison, judged out the best machine learning model. Further through the optimal model for screening physical features were evaluated for importance, judging out factors affecting ΔGH, providing direct guidance for predicting ΔGH of TMPs. The work in this article provides new and promising design and insights for using machine learning to predict the ΔGH of TMPs. 2 Compution details 2.1 Computational method This article calculates the relevant electronic properties through the CASTEP module of the Materials studio quantum calculation software. The exchange correlation energy is calculated using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional under the generalized gradient approximation (GGA), and the cutoff energy is set to 450 eV. For the structural optimization of the constructed catalyst model, the K-point grid in the Brillouin zone is selected as 7 × 7 × 1. For the calculation of the energy band, the K-point grid in the Brillouin zone is selected as 9 × 9 × 1. For the calculation of the density of states, MonkhorstPack type K-points are selected as 12 × 12 × 1 [31]. Considering the strong Coulomb exchange interaction between transition metal d-level electrons, and weak van der Waals force correction is performed through the DFT-D method [32]. The electronic structure analysis is calculated by OTFG ultra-soft pseudopotential. In order to avoid interference from periodic arrangement and eliminate interlayer atomic interaction forces, the vacuum layer thickness is selected as 20Å. The optimization of geometric structures stops when the force and energy criteria reach 0.1 eV/Å and 10−6 eV respectively, and when the maximum displacement tolerance is 0.01 Å, at which point the total energy of the system is also at its lowest, ensuring that the established model is closer to the structure of actual crystals. Gibbs free energy (ΔG H*): The Gibbs free energy of hydrogen precipitation can intuitively reflect the ability of catalysts to reduce H atoms. The calculation of free energy for H adsorption, ΔG H*, in HER follows the definition described by Nørskov et al. [33]. That is: (1) Δ G H * = Δ E H + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S H In type, the ΔE ZPE and ΔS H are the entropy difference between the adsorption state and the gas phase of zero point energy and H, respectively, which can be obtained by the equation: (2) Δ E Z P E = E Z P E ( H * ) − 1 2 E Z P E ( H 2 ) (3) Δ S = S ( H * ) − 1 2 S ( H 2 ) ≈ − 1 2 S ( H 2 ) In Nørskov's work [34], the ΔEZPE value of hydrogen adsorption on different metallic surfaces was considered to be 0.04 eV. Where S (H2) is the entropy of H2 in the gas phase at standard condition. Considering that TS (H2) is 0.40 eV for H2 at 298 K and 1 atm, the corresponding TΔS was determined to be −0.20 eV. * denotes a site on the electrode surface. When the absolute value of ΔG H* is zero, the HER catalytic activity is the best. 2.2 ML evaluation In order to effectively capture the performance of various available machine learning methods, our work adopted a variety of different regression algorithms, including K-nearest neighbor regressor (KNR) [35], kernel ridge regressor (KRR)[36], support vector regressor (SVR)[37], linear regression (LR)[38], gradient boosting regressor (GBR) [39], extreme gradient boosting regressor (XGBR)[40], random forest regressor (RFR)[41], decision tree regression (DTR), and the Ensemble learning algorithm model that combines the above algorithms. The machine learning schematic diagram is shown in Fig. 1 . All machine learning models in this paper were trained and evaluated using the Scikit-Learn package [42,43] in Python. Specifically, to ensure the stability of the model, we employed a grid search strategy with 5-fold cross-validation [44] to find the optimal combination of hyperparameters for the random forest model. Grid search is an exhaustive search method that sets a group of candidate values for each hyperparameter, then generates the Cartesian product of these candidate values to form a grid of hyperparameter combinations. Subsequently, grid search trains and evaluates the model for each combination of hyperparameters to find the combination with the best performance, thus improving the prediction accuracy and robustness of the model. The optimal hyperparameters for specific algorithm models are detailed in the supplementary literature. In order to evaluate the dependence between our machine learning features, we calculated the Pearson correlation coefficient (p) [45] for each pair of feature descriptors according to the following formula: (4) p = ∑ i ( a i − a ) ( b i − b ¯ ) ∑ i ( a i − a ¯ ) 2 ∑ i ( b i − b ¯ ) 2 Where ai and bi are the i th record values of the two features being compared, and a̅ and b̅ represent their respective average values. The resulting p-value is a number between 1 and −1, indicating a strong positive or negative correlation between the two given features, while a p-value close to 0 indicates weak or no correlation. For XGBR (a decision tree-based regression model), the calculation of feature importance is based on the improvement of the performance index at each feature split point, and is weighted according to the number of observations responsible for the node. The final feature importance is averaged across all trees and normalized between 1 and 0, with higher values corresponding to increased importance, and the sum of all feature importances being 1. For specific calculations of feature importance, please refer to the references. The prediction accuracy of machine learning models is evaluated based on root mean square error (RMSE)[46], mean absolute error (MAE)[47], and coefficient of determination (R²)[48], with their calculation formulas as follows: (5) R 2 = 1 − ∑ i = 1 n ( y i − y ^ i ) 2 ∑ i = 1 n ( y i − y ¯ ) 2 (6) RMSE = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n ( y i − y ^ i ) 2 (7) M A E = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n | y i − y i ^ | (8) importance ( j ) = ∑ t = 1 T gain ( t ) · I ( v ( t ) = j ) ∑ t = 1 T gain ( t ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Reparation of feature and target variables In this work, the dataset was manually collected from 60 published papers (the sources of the literature can be found in the supplementary information). TMPs are a class of materials composed of transition metals and phosphorus elements. The characteristic of their crystal structure is that they are composed alternately of transition metal ions and phosphorus ions. The collected data basically includes binary phosphides and ternary phosphides. Each of these systems has unique chemical and physical properties, so they have various applications in different fields, including catalysts, battery materials, energy storage, magnetic materials, etc. Ternary TMPs can be described as MXNYP, where M is the doping element and N is the main metal element of the phosphide. The transition metal elements covered by M and N include vanadium (V), chromium (Cr), manganese (Mn), iron (Fe), cobalt (Co), nickel (Ni), copper (Cu), zinc (Zn), silver (Ag), platinum (Pt), gold (Au), tungsten (W) and other transition metal elements. At the same time, in order to make up for the problem that there are missing systems in the data in the paper, we obtained 50 ΔGH data from our group's calculations and experiments. This dataset basically covers the systems of commonly used transition metal phosphide catalysts. According to the collected information, we began to explore the feature engineering of machine learning for the collected dataset. First, we collected easily available electronic properties and geometric properties of over-transition metal elements. The electronic properties include: first ionization energy, second ionization energy, electronegativity, atomic number, valence electron number, electron affinity energy, d orbital electron number, p orbital electron number, Geometric properties include atomic mass, atomic volume, atomic radius, van der Waals radius and covalent bond radius. In order to further improve the prediction accuracy of the model, 36 combined features that can be obtained through simple mathematical operations were added based on these 14 independent features. The main operations are arithmetic mean and geometric mean. All 36 features are summarized in Table 1 . To delve further into the intricate properties that can delineate the Gibbs free energy, we introduced an open source software package based on Python called matminer [49]. Matminer is a Python package for materials science that provides many convenient tools to support the process of extracting, preprocessing, analyzing, and visualizing data from materials data. In the field of chemistry, matminer can help chemists study the structure, properties, and applications of materials, providing more efficient and accurate tools for material design and discovery. By using this package, we increased the number of characteristic descriptors in our dataset from 36 to 192. To avoid this problem, we must take appropriate measures to eliminate redundant information in the dataset. It is important to note that a relatively large feature space does not necessarily lead to more accurate predictions due to the phenomenon of the 'Curse of Dimensionality'. In high-dimensional space, data becomes sparser, leading to overfitting of the model and increased computation time [50]. Consequently, we adopted a strict feature selection process to eliminate features with low importance or high correlation. We used XGBR to generate a ranking graph of the relative importance of each feature. The dependency information between features was obtained by plotting a heatmap of the Pearson correlation coefficient between each pair of features. The ranking graphs of all feature descriptors for ΔGH are shown in Supporting Data Figure S1. It should be noted that the research on data screening in the feature engineering stage is mainly based on XGBR because it uses regularization techniques to reduce the risk of overfitting and uses parallel processing to improve computational speed. In later sections, XGBR is also compared with other algorithm models. To determine the most suitable feature space, we first performed a preliminary screening of the entire dataset. By using the feature importance ranking graph and Pearson correlation coefficient graph of XGBR, we removed feature descriptors with low importance rankings and those with high correlation. Finally, 16 feature descriptors with high contribution to the model were retained. For these 16 feature descriptors, we used the RFE recursive dimensionality reduction algorithm [51] to iteratively remove low-ranking and highly dependent features from the dataset. It can be observed that as the feature space decreases, the model error and computation time show a gradually decreasing trend. As shown in the Fig. 2 , when the feature dimension is reduced to 8 dimensions, the lowest model errors (RMSE and MAE) of 0.062 and 0.027 are obtained. As the feature dimension is further reduced to 7 dimensions, the model error increases significantly. This information indicates that retaining 8 dimensions of feature descriptors is an appropriate stopping point. Such low error is sufficient for a rough estimate of ΔGH of TMPs reported in machine learning applications. The final eight features include five electronic features and three geometric features, namely: atomic volume of metal plus dopant (dAV+mAV), average d-orbital electron number (ANd), average electron affinity (AEa), geometric mean of first ionization energy (AFIE), first ionization energy of metal plus dopant (dFIE+mFIE), geometric mean of p-orbital electron number (GNp), geometric mean of covalent bond radius (GCr), and one from the matminer library. Their relative importance and correlation are illustrated in Fig. 2. 3.3 Model performance comparisons In terms of machine learning model comparison, we adopted 4 linear and nonlinear machine learning algorithms, namely KNR (Kernel Nearest Neighbors Regression), SVR (Support Vector Machine with linear kernel), KRR (Kernel Ridge Regressor), and LR (Linear Regression). In terms of tree-based models, we selected RFR (Random Forest Regression), DTR (Decision Tree Regression), GBR (Gradient Boosting Regression), and XGBR (Extreme Gradient Boosting Regression). In terms of Ensemble learning algorithms, we used combinations of non-tree and tree-based algorithms, as well as combinations of tree-based algorithms to fully utilize their advantages and improve the performance and generalization ability of the overall learner. This reduces the risk of overfitting and improves the robustness and stability of the model. To evaluate the performance of the four non-tree-based ML model algorithms, we used R² and RMSE to assess the fitting effect of these four models. For the non-tree-based machine learning algorithm models in this paper, all four selected linear machine learning algorithms exhibit varying degrees of overfitting. The specific prediction results are shown in Fig. 3 . The KNR algorithm has an R² value of 0.47 and an RMSE of 0.125 on the test set. Linear regression has an R² value of 0.44 and an RMSE of 0.128 on the test set. Kernel Ridge Regression (KRR) has an R² value of 0.28 and an RMSE of 0.14 on the test set. Linear regression has an R² value of 0.47 on the test set. The specific values of R² and RMSE for the model can be found in Supporting Data Table 1. It can be seen that non-tree-based algorithms cannot well describe the relationship between the selected feature values and ΔGH . The R2 values of the four tree-based models on the test set are all greater than 0.81, and the specific values of R2 and RMSE of the model can be found in Supporting Data Table 2. The specific prediction results of the four tree-based models are shown in Fig. 4 . Among them, the R2 value of RFR on the test set reached 0.89, with an RMSE of 0.06, demonstrating good model performance. The R2 of the GBR algorithm is 0.85, with an RMSE of 0.0668. The R2 value of the decision tree regression algorithm is 0.85, with an RMSE of 0.0668. The R2 value of the XGBR regression algorithm is 0.82, with an RMSE of 0.071. It can be seen that tree-based algorithms can well describe the relationship between the selected feature values and the target value Gibbs free energy, especially the random forest algorithm (RFR). In this study, we set candidate values for three hyperparameters of the random forest model [52]: max_depth (maximum depth of the tree) was set to 5, 10, and 15; min_samples_leaf (minimum number of samples at a leaf node) was set to 1, 2, and 4; n_estimators (number of trees) was set to 50, 100, and 150. After grid search, we found that the optimal combination of hyperparameters was: max_depth=10, min_samples_leaf=2, n_estimators=150. This combination achieved an accuracy of 0.89 on the validation set, higher than any other combination of hyperparameters, demonstrating good predictive performance. This can also indicate that there is not a purely linear correlation between the intrinsic properties of the catalyst and the free energy of the hydrogen evolution reaction, but rather a more complex coupling relationship. This is the significance of using machine learning, which can reduce the amount of experimental and theoretical calculations required for research in this area. Regarding the assessment of predictive performance, we note that relevant literature [27,53] also adopts the R² value as an evaluation metric. The R² values of the machine learning models used in these studies range from 0.81 to 0.91, which falls within a reasonable range. The results obtained from our predictions in this study also fall within this interval, indicating good predictive performance. 3.4 Ensemble learning algorithms In ensemble learning, multiple machine learning models (from model 1 to model n, i.e., weak learners) are combined into an ensemble model to achieve better prediction results (i.e., strong learners). Each weak learner can be a different instance of the same algorithm or a different type of machine learning algorithm [54]. Each weak learner learns and predicts from the data, generating its own prediction results. Then, these prediction results are integrated by the ensemble model, usually through voting or weighted averaging, to produce the final prediction result. The ensemble model can achieve more accurate and stable predictive ability than a single model by synthesizing the opinions of multiple weak learners. In this paper, we use the Ensemble learning algorithm in Python sklearn. We combine the non-tree-based algorithm models and tree-based algorithm models used in this paper, and combine tree-based algorithm models with tree-based models to predict the dataset. The basic flowchart of the ensemble learning algorithm is shown in Fig. 5 . In order to further improve the predictive performance, stability, and robustness of machine learning models, we combine non-tree-based algorithms with tree-based algorithms in the Ensemble learning algorithm to form a strong learner for ensemble learning: GBR+KRR, XGB+KRR, DTR+KRR, RFR+KRR, GBR+KNR, XGB+KNR, DTR+KNR, RFR+KNR, GBR+LR, XGB+LR, DTR+LR, RFR+LR, GBR+SVR, XGB+SVR, DTR+SVR, RFR+SVR. The distribution of the model's R² on the training and test sets is shown in Fig. 6 . The specific values of the model's R² and RMSE can be found in Supporting Data Table 3. Obviously, the strong learner composed of two weak learners has improved the non-tree-based algorithms that originally had overfitting to a certain extent. We paired the 4 selected tree-based models to form 6 ensemble learning algorithms: RFR+DTR, RFR+GBR, RFR+XGBR, DTR+GBR, DTR+XGBR, XGBR+GBR. We trained the corresponding algorithms on the dataset to obtain their datasets as shown in the Fig. 7 . From the Fig. 7, it can be seen that the mutual pairing of tree-based models has also greatly improved their predictive performance. As shown in Fig. 7, the R² values of the ensemble learning algorithms on the test set have all reached above 0.85. The specific values of the model's R² and RMSE can be found in Supporting Data Table 4. In contrast, we have also combined the four non-tree-based algorithms mentioned in this article, resulting in six ensemble learning algorithms: KNR+KRR, KNR+LR, KNR+SVR, LR+KRR, LR+SVR, and SVR+KRR. However, we encountered challenges in using non-tree-based base learners to effectively describe the relationship between the selected features and ΔGH. As a result, the improvement achieved by ensemble learning algorithms using non-tree-based algorithms is not significant. The specific prediction results can be found in the supporting data Table S6. The above results show that ensemble learning algorithms can not only effectively describe the relationship between feature descriptors and the target value ΔGH, but also have a positive impact on improving the predictive performance of basic weak learners. Therefore, Ensemble learning algorithm is an effective method to improve the predictive performance and stability of models. To increase and verify the credibility of the model, we randomly combined the data of 10 newly calculated transition metal phosphides using the trained ensemble learning algorithm model. The trained model was called using the joblib library in Python, and the organized data was read for prediction. Fig. 8 shows a line comparison chart of the calculated and predicted values for these 10 new data points. The specific information of the 10 data points used for prediction can be found in Supporting Data Table S8. 4 Feature importance analysis In the previous section, we confirmed that tree-based ensemble algorithms can effectively establish the correlation between feature descriptors and the free energy of hydrogen evolution reactions. Further, clarifying important features can also accelerate the design of excellent hydrogen evolution electrocatalysts. We used both random forest (RFR) feature importance and SHAP methods to interpret the "black box model" of machine learning algorithms, revealing the importance and influence of features on model prediction from both global and local levels by calculating the marginal contribution of features to model output. Among them, SHAP Summary Plot is a visualization tool that can intuitively understand the contribution of each feature to different prediction results [55]. Fig. 9 shows the analysis and ranking of global and local feature importance for eight feature descriptors using random forest and SHAP methods. The results show that the global feature importance and local feature importance of different features have similar distribution trends, proving the consistency of feature importance results. Among them, the geometric mean of P orbital electron number (GNp) ranks first in both global feature importance and local feature importance, while the atomic volume of metal and doping (dAV+mAV) and the geometric mean of first ionization energy (AFIE) have a considerable impact on the prediction results of the model. Through the above results, combined with our professional knowledge for analysis,the positive impact of TMPs in electrocatalysis mainly comes from the adjustment of P orbital electron number [56–58]and the change of atomic volume [59]. These adjustments can optimize the electronic structure, adsorption ΔGH electron coupling strength and transfer efficiency, as well as improve the active site and catalyst stability. Through these adjustments, transition metal phosphide electrocatalysts can improve catalytic activity, reaction efficiency and durability, thus having important application value in the field of electrocatalysis. Similarly, the first ionization energy has a positive impact on the ΔGH of transition metal phosphide electrocatalysts in several aspects: adjusting the electronic structure, optimizing the active site, improving electron transfer and enhancing catalyst stability. By adjusting the first ionization energy [60], the electronic structure and active site of the catalyst can be optimized, the electron transfer path can be improved, and the stability of the catalyst can be enhanced, thereby improving its electrocatalytic performance, reaction efficiency and durability. Covalent bond radius is an important factor affecting the ΔGH of transition metal phosphide electrocatalysts [61]. Adjusting the covalent bond radius can optimize the active site of the catalyst, improve conductivity, adjust the structure of the catalyst and enhance stability. These adjustments can reduce ΔGH improve catalytic efficiency and performance. Therefore, regulation of covalent bond radius provides a theoretical basis and guidance for developing efficient and low-cost electrocatalysts. The data from other items also made positive contributions to ΔGH to varying degrees. 5 Conclusion The aim of this study is to find low-cost and high-performance catalysts to promote the development of the electrolytic water hydrogen evolution industry. In this paper, by increasing the amount and type of data, using more advanced machine learning algorithms, and combining different types of algorithms, we achieved the prediction of ΔGH of TMPs. Tree-based, non-tree-based and ensemble algorithms were used to effectively evaluate the hydrogen evolution free energy and to reasonably rank and analyze important feature values. The results show that tree-based algorithms effectively describe the relationship between selected features and the target value ΔGH, with the random forest (RFR) algorithm achieving a prediction accuracy of 0.89. It reveals that the correlation between catalysts’ inherent characteristics and catalytic properties is not simply linear, highlighting machine learning's advantages in guiding design. The ensemble learning algorithm, combining non-tree-based and tree-based techniques, significantly improved overfitting non-tree-based algorithms. After combining tree-based algorithms using ensemble learning algorithms, the R2 values of tree-based combined algorithms on the test set elevated over 0.86, increasing the model's overall stability and resilience while maintaining reasonable accuracy in prediction. However, our research still has some limitations. For example, there is a large bias in the dataset we searched in the paper, so the generalization ability of the model is also limited. In future catalyst development, more complete model data should be constructed to measure computational-experimental-machine learning data as uniformly as possible. This study provides useful insights and guidance for future research, and we look forward to more breakthroughs in this field in future research. coredata.dc:description: Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) are potential substitutes for platinum group metal catalysts in hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) for sustainable energy. In this work, a novel machine learning (ML)-based technique for HER performance prediction of TMPs is presented. ΔGH, which assesses catalytic activity, was utilized as the expected target value and data from sources like collected papers and self-calculated data were also employed. The random forest (RFR) technique produced an R2 of 0.89 on the test set, while non-tree ML algorithms were utilized for learning and feedback. Additionally, TMPs of ΔGH were predicted using an original Ensemble learning technique. The ensemble learning method significantly increased the model's predictive effect and strengthened the model's stability and resilience, resulting in an R2 >0.85 on the test set for the tree algorithm model. The SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) algorithm and RFR showed that the geometric means of atomic volume, first ionization energy, and p-orbital electron number significantly impact free energy performance evaluation by tree ML algorithms. These findings can effectively guide the design and development of new products. In conclusion, this approach offers a useful tool to assess TMPs’ performance in HER studies.
coredata.dc:title: Accelerating the design and optimization of catalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction in transition metal phosphides using machine learning
